content.raw: You can remove `map` and `math/Angle`, since they're not used. You can also move `vector` to the cc file because it's not needed in the header.
content.html: You can remove map and math/Angle, since they're not used. You can also move vector to the cc file because it's not needed in the header.

content.raw: :ok_hand:

You don't need to declare `Waypoint` because it's not used in the header.

On the other hand, `Animation` and `Trajectory` are needed by public functions, which means that downstream users will need their declarations. So instead of forward-declaring them we should move their declarations to `Actor.hh`.
content.html:
You don't need to declare Waypoint because it's not used in the header.

On the other hand, Animation and Trajectory are needed by public functions, which means that downstream users will need their declarations. So instead of forward-declaring them we should move their declarations to Actor.hh.

content.raw:
I copied from the Light.hh example, see [#!/osrf/sdformat/src/2fa714812545abeb5ae05a8aebf0047aeb35d6a4/include/sdf/Light.hh#lines-88](#!/osrf/sdformat/src/2fa714812545abeb5ae05a8aebf0047aeb35d6a4/include/sdf/Light.hh#lines-88)

I am not sure the meaning of the `const` here…:worried:
content.html:
I copied from the Light.hh example, see #!/osrf/sdformat/src/2fa714812545abeb5ae05a8aebf0047aeb35d6a4/include/sdf/Light.hh#lines-88

I am not sure the meaning of the const here…

content.raw: Oh that's bad, we should fix that. For now, let's just remove the `const` in the end here. When a function is const, it's telling the caller that it will not modify the class. But setters are always modifying the class, so they should never be const. On the other hand, getters should always be const.
content.html: Oh that's bad, we should fix that. For now, let's just remove the const in the end here. When a function is const, it's telling the caller that it will not modify the class. But setters are always modifying the class, so they should never be const. On the other hand, getters should always be const.

content.raw: Gotcha, thanks.
content.html: Gotcha, thanks.

content.raw: We've been inconsistent in the way we've been returning strings: some API returns by value and some returns by const reference. There are arguments for both, so I don't think there's a right answer here. I do think we should be consistent though. Would you mind changing `std::string Name() const` to `const std::string &Name() const` so it follows the same pattern as `SkinFilename` and `PoseFrame`?
content.html: We've been inconsistent in the way we've been returning strings: some API returns by value and some returns by const reference. There are arguments for both, so I don't think there's a right answer here. I do think we should be consistent though. Would you mind changing std::string Name() const to const std::string &Name() const so it follows the same pattern as SkinFilename and PoseFrame?

content.raw: No. Thanks for reminding. Yes, we should be consistent all the way.
content.html: No. Thanks for reminding. Yes, we should be consistent all the way.

content.raw: Are you sure it's between 0 and 1? So it can't be scaled up by 2 for example?
content.html: Are you sure it's between 0 and 1? So it can't be scaled up by 2 for example?

content.raw: Oh yes. It could be scaled up.
content.html: Oh yes. It could be scaled up.

content.raw: Name is an attribute, not an element (i.e. `<actor name="the_name">`, not `<actor><name>the_name</name>`), so this should be `ATTRIBUTE_MISSING`
content.html: Name is an attribute, not an element (i.e. <actor name="the_name">, not <actor><name>the_name</name>), so this should be ATTRIBUTE_MISSING
